subject: Re: [junit] Re: Junit testing of web services
msgSnippet: Cool Link - One of my favorite parts is this: Not Reacting Like A Loser Odds are you ll screw up a few times on hacker community forums — in ways detailed in
messageBody:
Cool Link - One of my favorite parts is this:

Not Reacting Like A Loser

Odds are you'll screw up a few times on hacker
community forums  in ways detailed in this article,
or similar. And you'll be told exactly how you screwed
up, possibly with colourful asides. In public.

When this happens, the worst thing you can do is whine
about the experience, claim to have been verbally
assaulted, demand apologies, scream, hold your breath,
threaten lawsuits, complain to people's employers,
leave the toilet seat up, etc. Instead, here's what
you do:


Man - No wonder I never get any answers - Should have
listened to my wife and put the toilet seat down while
breathing normally without making sound.



--- Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...>
wrote:

> On 9/2/06, vkv3056 <vkv3056@...> wrote:
> > Thanks for your response. But you could have
> safely assumed that
> > anyone asking for use of Junit for web services
> would necessarily
> > have common sense of using any of the major search
> engines. Instead
> > of sermons on helping me exercise search engine
> skills, some
> > concrete info would have been more useful (for
> example, look at
> > other responses on this topic).
>
> Oh, you've gotta love this. Someone who dumps a
> quick "please give me
> info about testing web services" email, is now
> taking me to task about
> not making dramatically unlikely assumptions about
> their level of
> knowledge.
>
> The vast majority of emails that come through this
> list of the type
> "pls u snd me junit info thnx" are from folks who
> have not used a
> search engine and who are lazy beyond belief. These
> folks are welcome
> to receive help when they start following the advice
> in ESR's "asking
> smart questions". For the record, I also suggest
> that you read it. You
> gave no indication that you had ever touched a
> search engine. You gave
> no indication that you knew anything about web
> services beyond the
> correct spelling of the words. Here's the link (see,
> I can be
> helpful):
>
> http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html
>
> I also noticed quite a large number of useful
> looking links when I
> googled for "testing web services junit". If I could
> find them, I have
> no idea why you couldn't.
>
> Simon
>
> --
> www.simonpeter.org
>
